    • collapse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> collapse(BiPredicate<? super T,? super T> collapsible)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a List. The predicate takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element and its previous element are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a List. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the previous element when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a BiPredicate that takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is a List of adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> collapse(BiPredicate<? super T,? super T> collapsible, Supplier<? extends C> supplier)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a Collection. The predicate takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element and its previous element are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a Collection. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the previous element when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Type Parameters:
      C - the type of the Collection into which the adjacent elements will be collapsed.
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a BiPredicate that takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      supplier - a Supplier that generates the Collection into which the adjacent elements will be collapsed.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is a Collection of adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> collapse(BiPredicate<? super T,? super T> collapsible, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,T> mergeFunction)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate using the merger function and returns a new stream. The predicate takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element and its previous element are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then merged using the provided BiFunction. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the previous element when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => []
 Stream.of(1).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [3]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [6]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [6, 3, 2, 1]
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a BiPredicate that takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      mergeFunction - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the result of the previous merge operation (or the first element if no merge has been performed yet) and the current element, and returns the result of the merge operation.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of merging adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <U> Stream<U> collapse(BiPredicate<? super T,? super T> collapsible, U init, BiFunction<? super U,? super T,U> mergeFunction)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single element using the provided operation and returns a new stream. The predicate takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element and its previous element are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then merged using the provided BiFunction. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the previous element when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Type Parameters:
      U - the type of the resulting elements.
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a BiPredicate that takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      init - the initial value to be used in the BiFunction for the first element if the predicate returns true.
      mergeFunction - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the initial value or the result of the merge function from the previous step, and the current element. It returns a single element that represents the collapsed elements.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of merging adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> collapse(BiPredicate<? super T,? super T> collapsible, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single element using the provided collector and returns a new stream. The predicate takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element and its previous element are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single element using the provided collector. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the previous element when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => []
 Stream.of(1).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [3]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [6]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).collapse((p, c) -> p < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [6, 3, 2, 1]
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a BiPredicate that takes two parameters: the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      collector - a Collector that collects the adjacent elements into a single element.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> collapse(TriPredicate<? super T,? super T,? super T> collapsible)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single list and returns a new stream. The predicate takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element, its previous element and the first element of the series are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single list. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the first and previous elements when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a TriPredicate that takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is a list that is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> collapse(TriPredicate<? super T,? super T,? super T> collapsible, Supplier<? extends C> supplier)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single collection and returns a new stream. The predicate takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element, its previous element and the first element of the series are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single collection. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the first and previous elements when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Type Parameters:
      C - the type of the Collection into which the adjacent elements will be collapsed
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a TriPredicate that takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      supplier - a Supplier that generates the collection into which the adjacent elements will be collapsed.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is a collection that is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> collapse(TriPredicate<? super T,? super T,? super T> collapsible, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,T> mergeFunction)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single element and returns a new stream. The predicate takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element, its previous element and the first element of the series are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single element using the provided merge function. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the first and previous elements when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => []
 Stream.of(1).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [3]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [6]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11, 1]
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a TriPredicate that takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      mergeFunction - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the current element and its previous element. It returns a single element that represents the collapsed elements.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <U> Stream<U> collapse(TriPredicate<? super T,? super T,? super T> collapsible, U init, BiFunction<? super U,? super T,U> mergeFunction)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single element and returns a new stream. The predicate takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element, its previous element and the first element of the series are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single element using the provided merge function. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the first and previous elements when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a TriPredicate that takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      init - the initial value to be used in the merge function for the first element in the series.
      mergeFunction - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the initial value or the result of the merge function from the previous step, and the current element. It returns a single element that represents the collapsed elements.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • collapse

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> collapse(TriPredicate<? super T,? super T,? super T> collapsible, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Merges a series of adjacent elements in the stream which satisfy the given predicate into a single element and returns a new stream. The predicate takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream. If the predicate returns true, the current element, its previous element and the first element of the series are considered as a series of adjacent elements. These elements are then collapsed into a single element using the provided collector. This is an intermediate operation, meaning it's always lazy. It doesn't start processing the data until a terminal operation is invoked on the stream pipeline. It's also a stateful operation since it needs to remember the first and previous elements when processing the current element. This operation is not parallelizable and requires the stream to be ordered.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => []
 Stream.of(1).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [3]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [6]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).collapse((f, p, c) -> f < c, Collectors.summingInt(Fn.unboxI())) => [11, 1]
      Parameters:
      collapsible - a TriPredicate that takes three parameters: the first element of the series, the previous element and the current element in the stream.
      collector - a Collector that collects the elements into a single result container.
      Returns:
      a new Stream where each element is the result of collapsing adjacent elements which satisfy the given predicate.

    • scan

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> scan(BiFunction<? super T,? super T,T> accumulator)
      Performs a scan (also known as prefix sum, cumulative sum, running total, or integral) operation on the elements of the stream. The scan operation takes a binary operator (the accumulator) and applies it cumulatively on the stream elements, successively combining each element in order from the start to produce a stream of accumulated results. For example, given a stream of numbers [1, 2, 3, 4], and an accumulator that performs addition, the output would be a stream of numbers [1, 3, 6, 10]. This is an intermediate operation. This operation is sequential only, even when called on a parallel stream.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).scan((r, c) -> r + c) => []
 Stream.of(1).scan((r, c) -> r + c) => [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2).scan((r, c) -> r + c) => [1, 3]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).scan((r, c) -> r + c) => [1, 3, 6]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).scan((r, c) -> r + c) => [1, 3, 6, 9, 11, 12]
      Parameters:
      accumulator - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the current accumulated value and the current stream element, and returns a new accumulated value.
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the results of the scan operation on the elements of the original stream.

    • scan

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <U> Stream<U> scan(U init, BiFunction<? super U,? super T,U> accumulator)
      Performs a scan (also known as prefix sum, cumulative sum, running total, or integral) operation on the elements of the stream. The scan operation takes an initial value and a binary operator (the accumulator) and applies it cumulatively on the stream elements, successively combining each element in order from the start to produce a stream of accumulated results. For example, given a stream of numbers [1, 2, 3, 4], an initial value of 10, and an accumulator that performs addition, the output would be a stream of numbers [11, 13, 16, 20]. This is an intermediate operation. This operation is sequential only, even when called on a parallel stream.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).scan(10, (r, c) -> r + c) => []
 Stream.of(1).scan(10, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11]
 Stream.of(1, 2).scan(10, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11, 13]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).scan(10, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11, 13, 16]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1).scan(10, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11, 13, 16, 19, 21, 22]
      Parameters:
      init - the initial value. It's only used once by the accumulator to calculate the first element in the returned stream. It will be ignored if this stream is empty and won't be the first element of the returned stream.
      accumulator - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the current accumulated value and the current stream element, and returns a new accumulated value.
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the results of the scan operation on the elements of the original stream.
      See Also:
      • scan(Object, boolean, BiFunction)

    • scan

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <U> Stream<U> scan(U init, boolean initIncluded, BiFunction<? super U,? super T,U> accumulator)
      Performs a scan (also known as prefix sum, cumulative sum, running total, or integral) operation on the elements of the stream. The scan operation takes an initial value and a binary operator (the accumulator) and applies it cumulatively on the stream elements, successively combining each element in order from the start to produce a stream of accumulated results.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).scan(10, false, (r, c) -> r + c) => []
 Stream.of(new Integer[0]).scan(10, true, (r, c) -> r + c) => [10]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).scan(10, false, (r, c) -> r + c) => [11, 13, 16]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).scan(10, true, (r, c) -> r + c) => [10, 11, 13, 16]
      This is an intermediate operation. This operation is sequential only, even when called on a parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      init - the initial value. It's only used once by the accumulator to calculate the first element in the returned stream.
      initIncluded - a boolean value that determines if the initial value should be included as the first element in the returned stream.
      accumulator - a BiFunction that takes two parameters: the current accumulated value and the current stream element, and returns a new accumulated value.
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the results of the scan operation on the elements of the original stream.
      See Also:
      • scan(Object, BiFunction)

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> split(int chunkSize)
      Returns a Stream of Lists, where each List contains a chunk of elements from the original stream. The size of each chunk is specified by the chunkSize parameter. The final chunk may be smaller if there are not enough elements.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      chunkSize - the desired size of each chunk (the last chunk may be smaller)
      Returns:
      a Stream of Lists, each containing a chunk of elements from the original stream
      See Also:
      • split(int, IntFunction)

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> split(int chunkSize, IntFunction<? extends C> collectionSupplier)
      Returns a Stream of Collections, where each Collection contains a chunk of elements from the original stream. The size of each chunk is specified by the chunkSize parameter. The final chunk may be smaller if there are not enough elements.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Type Parameters:
      C - the type of the Collection to be returned
      Parameters:
      chunkSize - the desired size of each chunk (the last chunk may be smaller)
      collectionSupplier - a function that provides a new collection of type C
      Returns:
      a Stream of Collections, each containing a chunk of elements from the original stream

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> split(int chunkSize, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Splits the elements of the stream into sub-streams of the specified size, each collected by the provided collector.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result produced by the collector.
      Parameters:
      chunkSize - The desired size of each sub stream (the last may be smaller).
      collector - The collector to be used for collecting elements of each sub stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of results produced by the collector for each sub stream.

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> split(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
      Splits the elements of the stream into sub-streams based on the provided predicate. Each sub-stream is collected into a List.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - The condition to be used for splitting the stream into sub-streams.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of Lists of elements from the original Stream.

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> split(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Supplier<? extends C> collectionSupplier)
      Splits the elements of the stream into collections based on the provided predicate.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Type Parameters:
      C - The type of the collection to be used for collecting elements of each sub stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - The condition to be used for splitting the stream into collections.
      collectionSupplier - The supplier function to provide a new collection for each sub stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of collections of elements from the original Stream.

    • split

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> split(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Splits the elements of the stream into separate streams based on the provided predicate.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result produced by the collector.
      Parameters:
      predicate - The condition to be used for splitting the stream.
      collector - The collector to be used for collecting elements of each substream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of elements from the original Stream collected by the provided collector.

    • splitAt

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<Stream<T>> splitAt(int where)
      Splits the stream into two parts at the specified index. The element at the specified index will be the first element of the second part The first part will be loaded into memory.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      where - The index at which to split the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of two sub-streams split at the given index.

    • splitAt

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> splitAt(int where, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Splits the stream into two parts at the specified index. The element at the specified index will be the first element of the second part The first part will be loaded into memory. This is an intermediate operation and can only be processed sequentially.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result produced by the collector.
      Parameters:
      where - The index at which to split the stream. The element at this index will be the first element of the second part.
      collector - The collector to be used for collecting elements of the first part of the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of elements from the first part of the original Stream collected by the provided collector.

    • splitAt

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<Stream<T>> splitAt(Predicate<? super T> where)
      Splits the stream into two parts based on the specified predicate. The first part will be loaded into memory.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      where - The predicate to determine where to split the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of two sub-streams split at the point where the predicate is satisfied.

    • splitAt

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> splitAt(Predicate<? super T> where, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Splits the stream into two parts based on the provided predicate. The first part will be loaded into memory.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result produced by the collector.
      Parameters:
      where - The condition at which to split the stream.
      collector - The collector to be used for collecting elements of the first part of the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of elements from the first part of the original Stream collected by the provided collector.

    • sliding

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> sliding(int windowSize)
      Creates a sliding window over the elements of the Stream, where each window is a List of elements. The window moves over the elements of the Stream according to the specified window size.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 4, 5).sliding(3) => [[1, 2, 3], [2, 3, 4], [3, 4, 5]]
      Parameters:
      windowSize - The size of the window to be used for sliding over the Stream elements.
      Returns:
      A new Stream where each element is a List of elements from the original Stream, representing a window.

    • sliding

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> sliding(int windowSize, IntFunction<? extends C> collectionSupplier)
      Creates a sliding window over the elements of the Stream, where each window is a collection of elements. The window moves over the elements of the Stream according to the specified window size.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      windowSize - The size of the window to be used for sliding over the Stream elements.
      collectionSupplier - The function to create a new collection for each window.
      Returns:
      A new Stream where each element is a collection of elements from the original Stream, representing a window.
      See Also:
      • sliding(int, int)

    • sliding

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <R> Stream<R> sliding(int windowSize, Collector<? super T,?,R> collector)
      Creates a sliding window over the elements of the Stream, where each window is a collection of elements. The window moves over the elements of the Stream according to the specified window size. The elements in each window are then collected into a result container using the provided Collector.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      windowSize - The size of the window to be used for sliding over the Stream elements.
      collector - The collector to be used for reduction of the elements in each window.
      Returns:
      A new Stream where each element is a result container of the collected elements from the original Stream, representing a window.
      See Also:
      • sliding(int, int)

    • sliding

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<List<T>> sliding(int windowSize, int increment)
      Creates a sliding window over the elements of the Stream, where each window is a List of elements. The window moves over the elements of the Stream according to the specified window size and increment. This is an intermediate operation and can only be processed sequentially.

      Example: 

       
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3, 4, 5).sliding(3, 2) => [[1, 2, 3], [3, 4, 5]]
      Parameters:
      windowSize - The size of the window to be used for sliding over the Stream elements.
      increment - The number of elements to move the window by each time.
      Returns:
      A new Stream where each element is a List of elements from the original Stream, representing a window.

    • sliding

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract <C extends Collection<T>> Stream<C> sliding(int windowSize, int increment, IntFunction<? extends C> collectionSupplier)
      Creates a sliding window over the elements of the Stream, where each window is a collection of elements. The window moves over the elements of the Stream according to the specified window size and increment.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      windowSize - The size of the window to be used for sliding over the Stream elements.
      increment - The number of elements to move the window by each time.
      collectionSupplier - The function to create a new collection for each window.
      Returns:
      A new Stream where each element is a collection of elements from the original Stream, representing a window.
      See Also:
      • sliding(int, int)

The elements in each window are then collected into a result container using the provided Collector.

    • intersperse

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> intersperse(T delimiter)
      Intersperses the given delimiter between the elements of the stream.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      For example: 
       
 Stream.of(1).intersperse(9) --> [1]
 Stream.of(1, 2, 3).intersperse(9) --> [1, 9, 2, 9, 3]
      Parameters:
      delimiter - The element to be inserted between each element of the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream with the delimiter interspersed between each element.

    • distinct

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public Stream<T> distinct(BinaryOperator<T> mergeFunction)
      Returns a stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream, where the duplicates are merged using the provided merge function. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      mergeFunction - a binary operator used to merge duplicate elements
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream

    • distinctBy

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> distinctBy(Function<? super T,?> keyMapper)
      Returns a stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream, where the distinctness is determined by the value mapped from the given key mapper function. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to extract the key for comparison
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream

    • distinctBy

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public Stream<T> distinctBy(Function<? super T,?> keyMapper, BinaryOperator<T> mergeFunction)
      Returns a stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream, where the distinctness is determined by the value mapped from the given key mapper function. Duplicates are merged using the provided merge function. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to extract the key for comparison
      mergeFunction - a binary operator used to merge duplicate elements
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the distinct elements of this stream

    • sorted

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> sorted(Comparator<? super T> comparator)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted according to the provided Comparator. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      comparator - a non-null Comparator to be used to compare stream elements
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the elements of the original stream, sorted according to the provided Comparator

    • sortedBy

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> sortedBy(Function<? super T,? extends Comparable> keyMapper)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted according to the natural order of the keys produced by the provided keyMapper function. Nulls are considered smaller than other values in the natural order. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a non-interfering, stateless function to apply to each element to determine its key for sorting
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the elements of the original stream, sorted according to the natural order of the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      See Also:
      • Comparators.comparingBy(Function)

    • sortedByInt

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> sortedByInt(ToIntFunction<? super T> keyMapper)

      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to extract the key for sorting
      Returns:
      a new Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted by the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      See Also:
      • Comparators.comparingInt(ToIntFunction)

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> reverseSortedByLong(ToLongFunction<? super T> keyMapper)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the long values produced by the provided keyMapper function. This is an intermediate operation.

      a new stream that contains the elements of the original stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      See Also:
      • Comparators.reversedComparingLong(ToLongFunction)

    • reverseSortedByDouble

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> reverseSortedByDouble(ToDoubleFunction<? super T> keyMapper)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the double values produced by the provided keyMapper function. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to extract the key for sorting
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the elements of the original stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      See Also:
      • Comparators.reversedComparingDouble(ToDoubleFunction)

    • reverseSortedBy

      @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp @TerminalOpTriggered public abstract Stream<T> reverseSortedBy(Function<? super T,? extends Comparable> keyMapper)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the keys produced by the provided keyMapper function. Nulls are considered bigger than other values in the reverse order. This is an intermediate operation.
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to apply to each element to determine its key for sorting
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the elements of the original stream, sorted in reverse order according to the natural order of the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      See Also:
      • Comparators.reversedComparingBy(Function)

    • top

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> top(int n)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the top n elements of this stream, according to the natural order of the elements. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      n - the number of top elements to select from the stream
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the top n elements of the original stream
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if n is less than zero

    • top

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> top(int n, Comparator<? super T> comparator)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the top n elements of this stream, sorted according to the provided Comparator. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      n - the number of top elements to select from the stream
      comparator - a non-null Comparator to be used to compare stream elements
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains the top n elements of the original stream, sorted according to the provided Comparator

    • skipRange

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> skipRange(int startInclusive, int endExclusive)
      Skips a range of elements in the stream. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      startInclusive - the first position in the range to skip, inclusive
      endExclusive - the last position in the range to skip, exclusive
      Returns:
      a new stream that skips the specified range of the original stream

    • skipNulls

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> skipNulls()
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, excluding null elements. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Returns:
      a new stream that excludes null elements of the original stream

    • skipLast

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> skipLast(int n)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the elements of this stream, excluding the last n elements. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream. A queue with size up to n will be maintained to filter out the last n elements. It may cause out of memory error if n is big enough.
      Parameters:
      n - the number of elements from the end of the stream to skip
      Returns:
      a new stream that excludes the last n elements of the original stream

    • last

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> last(int n)
      Returns a Stream consisting of the last n elements of this stream. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream. A queue with size up to n will be maintained to filter out the last n elements. It may cause out of memory error if n is big enough. All the elements will be loaded to get the last n elements and the Stream will be closed after that, if a terminal operation is triggered.
      Parameters:
      n - the number of elements from the end of the stream to include
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the last n elements of the original stream

    • onFirst

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> onFirst(Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action on the first element of the stream as it is consumed. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the first element of the stream
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the first element

    • onLast

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public abstract Stream<T> onLast(Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action on the last element of the stream as it is consumed. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Parameters:
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the last element of the stream
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the last element

    • peekFirst

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> peekFirst(Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action on the first element of the stream as it is consumed. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream. This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.
      Parameters:
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the first element of the stream
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the first element
      See Also:
      • onFirst(Consumer)

    • peekLast

      @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> peekLast(Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action on the last element of the stream as it is consumed. This is an intermediate operation and this method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream. This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.
      Parameters:
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the last element of the stream
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the last element
      See Also:
      • onLast(Consumer)

    • peekIf

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> peekIf(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action only on the elements pulled by downstream/terminal operation which satisfy the given predicate as they are consumed. This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.
      Parameters:
      predicate - a non-interfering predicate to test on the elements of the stream
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the elements pulled by downstream/terminal operation which satisfy the given predicate as they are consumed
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the elements that satisfy the predicate

    • peekIf

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> peekIf(BiPredicate<? super T,? super Long> predicate, Consumer<? super T> action) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Performs the provided action only on the elements pulled by downstream/terminal operation which satisfy the given predicate as they are consumed. The predicate takes two parameters: the current stream element and the count of iterated elements (starts with 1). This method is useful for debugging and logging purposes.
      Parameters:
      predicate - a non-interfering predicate to test on the elements of the stream and their iteration count
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the elements pulled by downstream/terminal operation which satisfy the given predicate as they are consumed
      Returns:
      a new stream that includes the action on the elements that satisfy the predicate
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the predicate or action is null

    • foreach

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public void foreach(Consumer<? super T> action)
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream. The action is a Consumer functional interface which accepts a single input argument and returns no result.
      Parameters:
      action - a non-interfering action to perform on the elements

    • forEach

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEach(Throwables.Consumer<? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream. The action is a Consumer functional interface which accepts a single input argument and returns no result.
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each element
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the Consumer
      See Also:
      • Consumer
      • Throwables.Consumer

    • forEachIndexed

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachIndexed(Throwables.IntObjConsumer<? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream, where the action is an instance of Throwables.IntObjConsumer. The action is a Consumer functional interface which accepts an index parameter and an element parameter.
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each element
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the Consumer
      See Also:
      • Throwables.IntObjConsumer

    • forEachUntil

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachUntil(Throwables.BiConsumer<? super T,MutableBoolean,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream until the action sets the MutableBoolean to true. Iteration on this stream will also be stopped when this flag is set to true.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that the action may throw
      Parameters:
      action - the action to be performed for each element, which accepts an element and a MutableBoolean
      Throws:
      E - if the action throws an exception
      See Also:
      • forEachUntil(MutableBoolean, Throwables.Consumer)

    • forEachUntil

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachUntil(MutableBoolean flagToBreak, Throwables.Consumer<? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream until the flagToBreak is set to true. Iteration on this stream will also be stopped when the flagToBreak is set to true. If the flagToBreak is set to true at the beginning, no elements will be iterated from the stream before it is stopped and closed.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that the action may throw
      Parameters:
      flagToBreak - a flag to break the for-each loop. Set it to true to break the loop if you don't want to continue the action. Iteration on this stream will also be stopped when this flag is set to true.
      action - the action to be performed for each element
      Throws:
      E - if the action throws an exception
      See Also:
      • forEachUntil(Throwables.BiConsumer)

    • forEach

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> void forEach(Throwables.Consumer<? super T,E> action, Throwables.Runnable<E2> onComplete) throws E, E2
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream After all elements have been processed by the Consumer, the provided Runnable is executed.
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each element
      onComplete - The Runnable to be executed after all elements have been processed
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the Consumer
      E2 - Exception thrown by the Runnable
      See Also:
      • N.forEach(Iterable, Throwables.Consumer)

    • forEach

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <U, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> void forEach(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends Iterable<? extends U>,E> flatMapper, Throwables.BiConsumer<? super T,? super U,E2> action) throws E, E2
      Transforms the elements in the stream by applying the flatMapper function to each element and then performs the provided action for each element of the Stream. The action is a BiConsumer functional interface which accepts an element of the Stream and an element of the Iterable produced by the flatMapper function.
      Type Parameters:
      U - The type of elements in the Iterable produced by the flatMapper function
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the flatMapper function
      E2 - The type of exception that can be thrown by the BiConsumer action
      Parameters:
      flatMapper - The function to transform elements of the Stream into Iterables
      action - The action to be performed for each element of the Stream and each element of the Iterable produced by the flatMapper function
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the flatMapper function
      E2 - Exception thrown by the BiConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEach(Iterable, Throwables.Function, Throwables.BiConsumer)

    • forEach

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <T2, T3, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception, E3 extends Exception> void forEach(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends Iterable<T2>,E> flatMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T2,? extends Iterable<T3>,E2> flatMapper2, Throwables.TriConsumer<? super T,? super T2,? super T3,E3> action) throws E, E2, E3
      Transforms the elements in the stream by applying the flatMapper/flatMapper2 function to each element and then performs the provided action for each element of the Stream. The action is a TriConsumer functional interface which accepts an element of the Stream and two elements of the Iterable produced by the flatMapper/flatMapper2 function.
      Type Parameters:
      T2 - The type of elements in the Iterable produced by the first flatMapper function
      T3 - The type of elements in the Iterable produced by the second flatMapper function
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the first flatMapper function
      E2 - The type of exception that can be thrown by the second flatMapper function
      E3 - The type of exception that can be thrown by the TriConsumer action
      Parameters:
      flatMapper - The first function to transform elements of the Stream into Iterables
      flatMapper2 - The second function to transform elements of the first Iterable into further Iterables
      action - The action to be performed for each element of the Stream and each element of the Iterables produced by the flatMapper functions
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the first flatMapper function
      E2 - Exception thrown by the second flatMapper function
      E3 - Exception thrown by the TriConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEach(Iterable, Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function, Throwables.TriConsumer)

    • forEachPair

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachPair(Throwables.BiConsumer<? super T,? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each pair of elements in the Stream. For the last non-paired element, the action is performed with the last element and null.
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the BiConsumer action
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each pair of elements
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the BiConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEachPair(Iterable, Throwables.BiConsumer)

    • forEachPair

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachPair(int increment, Throwables.BiConsumer<? super T,? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each pair of elements in the Stream, where the action is an instance of Throwables.BiConsumer. For the last non-paired element, the action is performed with the last element and null. The pairs are formed by taking elements at an interval specified by the increment parameter.
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the BiConsumer action
      Parameters:
      increment - The interval at which pairs of elements are formed
      action - The action to be performed for each pair of elements
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the BiConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEachPair(Iterable, int, Throwables.BiConsumer)

    • forEachTriple

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachTriple(Throwables.TriConsumer<? super T,? super T,? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each triple of elements in the Stream. For the last two non-tripled elements, the action is performed with the last two elements and null.
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the TriConsumer action
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each triple of elements
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the TriConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEachTriple(Iterable, Throwables.TriConsumer)

    • forEachTriple

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> void forEachTriple(int increment, Throwables.TriConsumer<? super T,? super T,? super T,E> action) throws E
      Performs the provided action for each triple of elements in the Stream. For the last two non-tripled elements, the action is performed with the last two elements and null. The triples are formed by taking elements at an interval specified by the increment parameter.
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the TriConsumer action
      Parameters:
      increment - The interval at which triples of elements are formed
      action - The action to be performed for each triple of elements
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the TriConsumer action
      See Also:
      • N.forEachTriple(Iterable, int, Throwables.TriConsumer)

    • anyMatch

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> boolean anyMatch(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Checks if any elements of this Stream match the provided predicate. This is a terminal operation.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that may be thrown by the predicate
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements of this stream
      Returns:
      true if any elements match the predicate, otherwise false
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception

    • allMatch

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> boolean allMatch(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Checks if all elements of this Stream match the provided predicate. This is a terminal operation.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that may be thrown by the predicate
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements of this stream
      Returns:
      true if all elements match the predicate or this Stream is empty, otherwise false
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception

    • noneMatch

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> boolean noneMatch(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Checks if no elements of this Stream match the provided predicate. This is a terminal operation.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that may be thrown by the predicate
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements of this stream
      Returns:
      true if no elements match the predicate or this Stream is empty, otherwise false
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception

    • nMatch

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> boolean nMatch(long atLeast, long atMost, Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Checks if the specified number of elements in the stream match the provided predicate.
      The operation stops as soon as the number of elements matching the predicate is bigger than atMost.
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of exception that can be thrown by the predicate
      Parameters:
      predicate - The predicate to apply to elements in the stream
      Returns:
      true if the number of elements matching the predicate is within the range [atLeast, atMost], false otherwise
      Throws:
      E - Exception thrown by the predicate

    • findFirst

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> u.Optional<T> findFirst(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Returns the first element in the stream that matches the provided predicate. If no element matches, an empty Optional is returned.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that the predicate may throw
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements in the stream
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the first matching element, or an empty Optional if no match is found
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception
      See Also:
      • findAny(Throwables.Predicate)

    • findAny

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> u.Optional<T> findAny(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Returns any element matched by the provided predicate if found. Otherwise, an empty Optional is returned. This method is similar to findFirst but may have better performance in parallel streams.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that the predicate may throw
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements in the stream
      Returns:
      an Optional containing any matching element, or an empty Optional if no match is found
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception
      See Also:
      • findFirst(Throwables.Predicate)

    • findLast

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <E extends Exception> u.Optional<T> findLast(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,E> predicate) throws E
      Returns the last element matched by the provided predicate if found. Otherwise, an empty Optional is returned. Consider using: stream.reversed().findFirst(predicate) for better performance when possible.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the type of exception that the predicate may throw
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to elements in the stream
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the last matching element, or an empty Optional if no match is found
      Throws:
      E - if the predicate throws an exception
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.reversed()
      • findFirst(Throwables.Predicate)

    • containsAll

      Checks if the stream contains all the specified elements.
      Parameters:
      a - the elements to check for presence in the stream
      Returns:
      true if the stream contains all the specified elements or the specified array is empty, false otherwise

      Checks if the stream contains all the specified elements.
      Parameters:

      Returns:
      true if the stream contains all the specified elements or the specified collection is empty, false otherwise

      Returns:

      Returns:

    • toArray

      @SequentialOnly @TerminalOp public abstract <A> A[] toArray(IntFunction<A[]> generator)
      Returns an array containing the elements of this stream. The provided generator function is used to allocate the returned array.
      Type Parameters:
      A - the component type of the array
      Parameters:
      generator - a function which produces a new array of the desired type and the provided length
      Returns:
      an array containing the elements of this stream

    • toImmutableMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public <K, V, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> ImmutableMap<K,V> toImmutableMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper) throws IllegalStateException, E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into an immutable map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      Returns:
      an immutable map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if there are duplicated keys
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toImmutableMap(Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function, BinaryOperator)
      • invalid reference 
        #toMap(Function, Function)
      • invalid reference 
        #toMap(Function, Function, BinaryOperator)
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • toImmutableMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public <K, V, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> ImmutableMap<K,V> toImmutableMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper, BinaryOperator<V> mergeFunction) throws E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into an immutable map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map. The provided mergeFunction is used to merge values associated with the same key.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      mergeFunction - the function to merge values associated with the same key
      Returns:
      an immutable map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toImmutableMap(Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function)
      • invalid reference 
        #toMap(Function, Function, BinaryOperator)
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • toMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> Map<K,V> toMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper) throws IllegalStateException, E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into a map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if there are duplicated keys
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toMap(Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function, BinaryOperator)
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • toMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> Map<K,V> toMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper, BinaryOperator<V> mergeFunction) throws E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into a map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map. The mergeFunction is used to to merge values associated with the same key.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      mergeFunction - the function to merge values associated with the same key
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toMap(Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function, BinaryOperator, Supplier)
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • toMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, M extends Map<K, V>, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> M toMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper, Supplier<? extends M> mapFactory) throws IllegalStateException, E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into a map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map. The mapFactory is used to create the resulting map.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      M - the type of the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      mapFactory - a supplier to create the resulting map
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if there are duplicated keys
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toMap(Throwables.Function, Throwables.Function, BinaryOperator, Supplier)
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • toMap

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, M extends Map<K, V>, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> M toMap(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper, BinaryOperator<V> mergeFunction, Supplier<? extends M> mapFactory) throws E, E2
      Collects the elements of this stream into a map. The provided keyMapper and valueMapper functions are used to produce the keys and values for the map. The mergeFunction is used to merge values associated with the same key. The mapFactory is used to create the resulting map.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      V - the type of values in the resulting map
      M - the type of the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      valueMapper - a function to produce the values for the map
      mergeFunction - the function to merge values associated with the same key
      mapFactory - a supplier to create the resulting map
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream
      Throws:
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Fn.throwingMerger()
      • Fn.replacingMerger()
      • Fn.ignoringMerger()

    • groupTo

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, E extends Exception> Map<K,List<T>> groupTo(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper) throws E
      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function. The resulting map will contain keys produced by the keyMapper function and values as lists of elements that map to the same key.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream grouped by the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      Throws:
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • toMultimap(Throwables.Function)

    • groupTo

      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function. The resulting map will contain keys produced by the keyMapper function and values as lists of elements that map to the same key. The provided mapFactory is used to create the resulting map.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      M - the type of the resulting map

      Parameters:

    • groupTo

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> Map<K,List<V>> groupTo(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper) throws E, E2
      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function. The resulting map will contain keys produced by the keyMapper function and values as lists of elements that map to the same key. The provided valueMapper function is used to produce the values for the map.

      V - the type of values in the resulting map

      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw

      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception

    • groupTo

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, V, M extends Map<K, List<V>>, E extends Exception, E2 extends Exception> M groupTo(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends V,E2> valueMapper, Supplier<? extends M> mapFactory) throws E, E2
      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function. The resulting map will contain keys produced by the keyMapper function and values as lists of elements that map to the same key.       V - the type of values in the resulting map

      E2 - the type of exception that the valueMapper function may throw

      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      E2 - if the valueMapper function throws an exception

    • groupTo

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, D, E extends Exception> Map<K,D> groupTo(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Collector<? super T,?,D> downstream) throws E
      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function. The resulting map will contain keys produced by the keyMapper function and values as collections of elements that map to the same key, reduced using the provided downstream collector.
      Type Parameters:
      K - the type of keys in the resulting map
      D - the type of the result of the downstream reduction
      E - the type of exception that the keyMapper function may throw
      Parameters:
      keyMapper - a function to produce the keys for the map
      downstream - a collector to reduce the values associated with a key
      Returns:
      a map containing the elements of this stream grouped by the keys produced by the keyMapper function
      Throws:
      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Collectors.groupingBy(Function, Collector)

    • groupTo

      @ParallelSupported @TerminalOp public abstract <K, D, M extends Map<K, D>, E extends Exception> M groupTo(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends K,E> keyMapper, Collector<? super T,?,D> downstream, Supplier<? extends M> mapFactory) throws E
      Groups the elements of this stream by a key produced by the provided keyMapper function.       downstream - a collector to reduce the values associated with a key

      E - if the keyMapper function throws an exception
