      mapper - The mapping function to apply to each element.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the results of applying the given function to the elements of this stream.
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.sps(int, Function)

    • spsFlatMap

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> spsFlatMap(int maxThreadNum, Function<? super T,? extends Stream<? extends R>> mapper)
      Temporarily switches the stream to a parallel stream for the operation flatMap and then switches it back to a sequential stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Type Parameters:

    • spsFlatmap

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> spsFlatmap(int maxThreadNum, Function<? super T,? extends Collection<? extends R>> mapper)
      Temporarily switches the stream to a parallel stream for the operation flatmap and then switches it back to a sequential stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the elements in the returned stream.
      Parameters:
      maxThreadNum - The maximum number of threads to be used for parallel execution.
      mapper - The mapping function to apply to each element, which produces a collection of new values.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the results of applying the given function to the elements of this stream.
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.sps(int, Function)

    • spsOnEach

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> spsOnEach(int maxThreadNum, Consumer<? super T> action)
      Temporarily switches the stream to a parallel stream for the operation onEach and then switches it back to a sequential stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Parameters:
      maxThreadNum - The maximum number of threads to be used for parallel execution.
      action - The action to be performed on each element of the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream with the specified action applied in parallel.
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.sps(int, Function)

    • spsFilter

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> spsFilter(int maxThreadNum, int chunkSize, Predicate<? super T> predicate)
      Temporarily switch the stream to parallel stream for operation filter and then switch back to stream stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Parameters:
      maxThreadNum - The maximum number of threads to be used for parallel execution.
      chunkSize - The size of chunks to split the stream into for parallel processing.
      predicate - The predicate to be used for the filter operation on the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream that has been filtered in parallel using the provided predicate.
      See Also:
      • sps(int, int, Function)

    • spsMap

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> spsMap(int maxThreadNum, int chunkSize, Function<? super T,? extends R> mapper)
      Temporarily switches the stream to a parallel stream for the operation map and then switches it back to a sequential stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the elements in the resulting stream.
      Parameters:
      maxThreadNum - The maximum number of threads to be used for parallel execution.
      chunkSize - The size of chunks to split the stream into for parallel processing.
      mapper - The function to be applied to each element of the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream that has been mapped in parallel using the provided mapper function.
      See Also:
      • sps(int, int, Function)

    • spsFlatMap

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> spsFlatMap(int maxThreadNum, int chunkSize, Function<? super T,? extends Stream<? extends R>> mapper)

    • sjps

      @Beta @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> sjps(Function<? super Stream<T>,? extends Stream<? extends R>> op)
      Temporarily switches the stream to a JDK parallel stream for the operation op and then switches it back to a sequential stream. This method is useful for performing a specific operation in parallel while keeping the rest of the stream operations sequential.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the elements in the resulting stream.
      Parameters:

      Returns:

    • filterE

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> filterE(Throwables.Predicate<? super T,? extends Exception> predicate)
      Filters the elements of this stream using the provided predicate.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to apply to each element to determine if it should be included
      Returns:
      a new stream that contains only the elements that match the predicate
      Throws:
      Exception - if the predicate throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Fn.pp(Throwables.Predicate)

    • mapE

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> mapE(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends R,? extends Exception> mapper)
      Transforms the elements in the stream by applying a function to each element. This is an intermediate operation.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result elements.
      Parameters:
      mapper - The function to be applied to each element in the stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the results of applying the given function to the elements of this stream.
      Throws:
      Exception - if the mapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Fn.ff(Throwables.Function)

    • flatMapE

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> flatMapE(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends Stream<? extends R>,? extends Exception> mapper)
      Transforms the elements in the stream by applying a function that returns a stream to each element, and then flattens the resulting streams into a single stream. This is an intermediate operation.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result elements.
      Parameters:
      mapper - The function to be applied to each element in the stream, which returns a stream.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the results of applying the given function to the elements of this stream, and then flattening the resulting streams.
      Throws:
      Exception - if the mapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Fn.ff(Throwables.Function)

    • flatmapE

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public <R> Stream<R> flatmapE(Throwables.Function<? super T,? extends Collection<? extends R>,? extends Exception> mapper)
      Transforms the elements in the stream by applying a function that returns a collection to each element, and then flattens the resulting collections into a single stream. This is an intermediate operation.
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of the result elements.
      Parameters:
      mapper - The function to be applied to each element in the stream, which returns a collection.
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the results of applying the given function to the elements of this stream, and then flattening the resulting collections.
      Throws:
      Exception - if the mapper function throws an exception
      See Also:
      • Fn.ff(Throwables.Function)

    • onEachE

      @Beta @ParallelSupported @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> onEachE(Throwables.Consumer<? super T,? extends Exception> action)
      Performs the provided action for each element of the Stream. The action is a Consumer that can throw an exception.
      Parameters:
      action - The action to be performed for each element, which can throw an exception
      Returns:
      The new Stream
      Throws:
      Exception - if the action throws an exception

      • What is the difference between "INNER JOIN" and "OUTER JOIN"

    • addSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction)
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements from upstream. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      See Also:
      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)

    • addSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction, int queueSize, long maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery, Executor executor) throws IllegalStateException, IllegalArgumentException
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements from upstream. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream. To get the return value of the attached stream, An output parameter can be used. for example: 
       
     final Holder resultHolder = new Holderinvalid input: '<'>();
     thisStream.addSubscriber(newStream -> resultHolder.set(newStream.filter(...).map(...).join(",")))...;
      Parameters:
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      queueSize - the size of the queue. Default value is 64.
      maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery - max wait time to add next element to queue for subscriber stream to consumer. Default value is 30000 (unit is milliseconds). If the next element can't be added to queue after waiting for period, exception will be thrown in subscriber stream.
      executor - the executor to run the attached stream
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException
      IllegalArgumentException

    • filterWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> filterWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction)
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements filtered out by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to test elements
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      See Also:
      • invalid reference 
        #filterWhileAddSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • invalid reference 
        #filter(Object, Consumer)

    • filterWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> filterWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction, int queueSize, long maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery, Executor executor) throws IllegalStateException, IllegalArgumentException
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements filtered out by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to test elements
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      queueSize - the size of the queue. Default value is 64.
      maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery - max wait time to add next element to queue for subscriber stream to consumer. Default value is 30000 (unit is milliseconds). If the next element can't be added to queue after waiting for period, exception will be thrown in subscriber stream.
      executor - the executor to run the attached stream
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException
      IllegalArgumentException
      See Also:
      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • invalid reference 
        #filter(Object, Consumer)

    • takeWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> takeWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction)
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements not token by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to test elements
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action

      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      See Also:
      • invalid reference

      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)

    • takeWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> takeWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction, Executor executor) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements not token by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:

    • dropWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> dropWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction)
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements dropped by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to test elements
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      See Also:
      • invalid reference 
        #dropWhileAddSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • invalid reference 
        #dropWhile(Object, Consumer)

    • dropWhileAddSubscriber

      @Beta @SequentialOnly @IntermediateOp public Stream<T> dropWhileAddSubscriber(Predicate<? super T> predicate, Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction, int queueSize, long maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery, Executor executor) throws IllegalStateException, IllegalArgumentException
      Attaches a new stream with terminal action to consume the elements dropped by the specified predicate. The Intermediate and terminate operations in the attached stream will be executed in a new Thread. The new thread is started when the main stream(the returned stream or its downstream) receives the first element or is closed if there is no element pulled. Elements from upstream pulled by the main stream will be put in a queue for the attached stream to consume. After the main stream is finished, the attached stream will continue to pull remaining elements from upstream if needed. The main stream and the attached stream run independently. Operations in one stream won't impact the elements or final result in another Stream. But when the main stream is to close, it will wait to the attached stream to close before calling close actions. So the attached stream may ends up earlier than the main stream, or at least no later than the main stream.
      Parameters:
      predicate - the predicate to test elements
      consumerForNewStreamWithTerminalAction - the consumer for the new stream with terminal action
      queueSize - the size of the queue. Default value is 64.
      maxWaitForAddingElementToQuery - max wait time to add next element to queue for subscriber stream to consumer. Default value is 30000 (unit is milliseconds). If the next element can't be added to queue after waiting for period, exception will be thrown in subscriber stream.
      executor - the executor to run the attached stream
      Returns:
      the main stream with the attached subscriber
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException
      IllegalArgumentException
      See Also:
      • addSubscriber(Throwables.Consumer, int, long, Executor)
      • invalid reference 
        #dropWhile(Object, Consumer)

    • asyncRun

      @Beta @TerminalOp public ContinuableFuture<Void> asyncRun(Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> terminalAction) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Executes the provided terminal operation asynchronously on this Stream. The terminal operation is a function that consumes this Stream and may throw an exception. The result of the operation is wrapped in a ContinuableFuture.
      Parameters:
      terminalAction - the terminal operation to be executed on this Stream
      Returns:
      a ContinuableFuture representing the result of the asynchronous computation
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if terminalAction is null

    • asyncRun

      @Beta @TerminalOp public ContinuableFuture<Void> asyncRun(Throwables.Consumer<? super Stream<T>,? extends Exception> terminalAction, Executor executor) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Executes the provided terminal operation asynchronously on this Stream using the specified Executor. The terminal operation is a function that consumes this Stream and may throw an exception. The result of the operation is wrapped in a ContinuableFuture.
      Parameters:
      terminalAction - the terminal operation to be executed on this Stream
      executor - the Executor to use for asynchronous execution
      Returns:
      a ContinuableFuture representing the result of the asynchronous computation
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if terminalAction is null

    • asyncCall

      @Beta @TerminalOp public <R> ContinuableFuture<R> asyncCall(Throwables.Function<? super Stream<T>,R,? extends Exception> terminalAction) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Executes the provided terminal operation asynchronously on this Stream. The terminal operation is a function that consumes this Stream and may throw an exception. The result of the operation is wrapped in a ContinuableFuture.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result of the terminal operation
      Parameters:
      terminalAction - the terminal operation to be executed on this Stream
      Returns:
      a ContinuableFuture representing the result of the asynchronous computation
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if terminalAction is null

    • asyncCall

      Executes the provided terminal operation asynchronously on this Stream using the specified Executor. The terminal operation is a function that consumes this Stream and may throw an exception. The result of the operation is wrapped in a ContinuableFuture.

      R - the type of the result of the terminal operation

      a ContinuableFuture representing the result of the asynchronous computation
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if terminalAction is null

      public static <T> Stream<T> empty()
      Returns an empty Stream.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the Stream
      Returns:
      an empty Stream

    • defer

      public static <T> Stream<T> defer(Supplier<? extends Stream<? extends T>> supplier) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Returns a Stream that is lazily populated by an input supplier.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the stream elements
      Parameters:
      supplier - the Supplier that generates the Stream
      Returns:
      a Stream instance
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the supplier is null

    • from

      public static <T> Stream<T> from(Stream<? extends T> stream)
      Creates a new Stream from the provided java.util.stream.Stream. The returned Stream will be sequential or parallel based on the provided java.util.stream.Stream. The provided stream will be closed once one of the terminal operations in the returned stream is executed or the returned stream is closed.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the Stream
      Parameters:
      stream - the java.util.stream.Stream to convert
      Returns:
      a new Stream containing the elements of the provided java.util.stream.Stream

    • just

      Creates a stream containing a single element.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the element
      Parameters:
      e - the element to be included in the stream
      Returns:
      a stream containing the specified element

    • ofNullable

      public static <T> Stream<T> ofNullable(T e)
      Returns an empty Stream if the specified element is null. Otherwise, returns a Stream containing the specified element.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the element
      Parameters:
      e - the element to be included in the stream, or null
      Returns:
      a stream containing the specified element, or an empty stream if the element is null

    • of

      @SafeVarargs public static <T> Stream<T> of(T... a)
      Returns a stream containing the specified elements.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements
      Parameters:
      a - the elements to be included in the stream
      Returns:
      a stream containing the specified elements. If the specified array is empty, an empty stream is returned.

    • of

      public static <T> Stream<T> of(T[] a, int startIndex, int endIndex) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException
      Returns a stream containing the specified elements from the given array, starting from the specified start index (inclusive) to the specified end index (exclusive).
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements
      Parameters:
      a - the array from which elements are to be included in the stream
      startIndex - the starting index (inclusive) of the array
      endIndex - the ending index (exclusive) of the array
      Returns:
      a stream containing the specified elements from the array
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the specified start index or end index is out of bounds

      @Deprecated public static <T> Stream<T> of(Stream<? extends T> stream)

      instead

      public static Stream<Integer> range(int startInclusive, int endExclusive, int by)

      Parameters:
      startInclusive - the starting value (inclusive)
      endExclusive - the ending value (exclusive)
      by - The step to increment (if positive) or decrement (if negative) for each subsequent integer
      Returns:
      a stream of integers from startInclusive (inclusive) to endExclusive (exclusive) with the specified step

    • splitToLines

      @Beta public static Stream<String> splitToLines(String str, boolean trim, boolean omitEmptyLines)
      Splits the given string into lines and returns a stream of the resulting lines. Optionally trims each line and omits empty lines based on the provided flags.
      Parameters:
      str - the string to be split into lines
      trim - whether to trim each line
      omitEmptyLines - whether to omit empty lines
      Returns:
      a stream of lines resulting from splitting the input string

    • splitByChunkCount

      public static <T> Stream<T> splitByChunkCount(int totalSize, int maxChunkCount, IntBiFunction<? extends T> mapper)
      Splits the total size into chunks based on the specified maximum chunk count.
      The size of the chunks is larger first.
      The length of returned Stream may be less than the specified maxChunkCount if the input totalSize is less than maxChunkCount.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the resulting stream
      Parameters:
      totalSize - the total size to be split. It could be the size of an array, list, etc.
      maxChunkCount - the maximum number of chunks to split into
      mapper - a function to map the chunk from and to index to an element in the resulting stream
      Returns:
      a Stream of the mapped chunk values
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if totalSize is negative or maxChunkCount is not positive.
      See Also:
      • splitByChunkCount(int, int, boolean, IntBiFunction)

    • splitByChunkCount

      public static <T> Stream<T> splitByChunkCount(int totalSize, int maxChunkCount, boolean sizeSmallerFirst, IntBiFunction<? extends T> mapper)
      Splits the total size into chunks based on the specified maximum chunk count.
      The size of the chunks can be either smaller or larger first based on the flag.
      The length of returned Stream may be less than the specified maxChunkCount if the input totalSize is less than maxChunkCount. 
       
 final int[] a = Array.rangeClosed(1, 7);
 splitByChunkCount(7, 5, true, (fromIndex, toIndex) ->  copyOfRange(a, fromIndex, toIndex)); // [[1], [2], [3], [4, 5], [6, 7]]
 splitByChunkCount(7, 5, false, (fromIndex, toIndex) ->  copyOfRange(a, fromIndex, toIndex)); // [[1, 2], [3, 4], [5], [6], [7]]
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the resulting stream
      Parameters:
      totalSize - the total size to be split. It could be the size of an array, list, etc.
      maxChunkCount - the maximum number of chunks to split into
      sizeSmallerFirst - if true, smaller chunks will be created first; otherwise, larger chunks will be created first
      mapper - a function to map the chunk from and to index to an element in the resulting stream
      Returns:
      a Stream of the mapped chunk values
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if totalSize is negative or maxChunkCount is not positive.
      See Also:
      • IntStream.splitByChunkCount(int, int, boolean, IntBinaryOperator)

    • flatten

      public static <T> Stream<T> flatten(Collection<? extends Collection<? extends T>> c)
      Flattens a collection of collections into a single stream of elements.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the collections
      Parameters:
      c - the collection of collections to be flattened
      Returns:
      a stream of elements from the flattened collections

    • flatten

      public static <T> Stream<T> flatten(T[][] a)
      Flattens a two-dimensional array into a single stream of elements.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the array
      Parameters:
      a - the two-dimensional array to be flattened
      Returns:
      a stream of elements from the flattened array

    • flatten

      public static <T> Stream<T> flatten(T[][] a, boolean vertically)
      Flattens a two-dimensional array into a single stream of elements.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the array
      Parameters:
      a - the two-dimensional array to be flattened
      vertically - if true, the array is flattened vertically; otherwise, it is flattened horizontally
      Returns:
      a stream of elements from the flattened array

    • flatten

      public static <T> Stream<T> flatten(T[][] a, T valueForAlignment, boolean vertically)
      Flattens a two-dimensional array into a single stream of elements, aligning the elements if necessary.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the array
      Parameters:
      a - the two-dimensional array to be flattened
      valueForAlignment - the element to append so there are the same number of elements in all rows/columns
      vertically - if true, the array is flattened vertically; otherwise, it is flattened horizontally
      Returns:
      a stream of elements from the flattened array

    • flatten

      public static <T> Stream<T> flatten(T[][][] a)

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the array
      Parameters:
      a - the three-dimensional array to be flattened
      Returns:
      a stream of elements from the flattened array

    • repeat

      public static <T> Stream<T> repeat(T element, long n) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a stream that repeats the given element a specified number of times.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the element
      Parameters:
      element - the element to be repeated
      n - the number of times to repeat the element
      Returns:
      a stream of the repeated element
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the number of repetitions is negative

    • iterate

      public static <T> Stream<T> iterate(BooleanSupplier hasNext, Supplier<? extends T> next) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a stream that iterates using the given hasNext and next suppliers.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the stream
      Parameters:
      hasNext - a BooleanSupplier that returns true if the iteration should continue
      next - a Supplier that provides the next element in the iteration
      Returns:
      a stream of elements generated by the iteration
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if hasNext or next is null

    • iterate

      public static <T> Stream<T> iterate(T init, BooleanSupplier hasNext, UnaryOperator<T> f) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Returns a sequential ordered Stream produced by iterative application of a function f to an initial element init, producing a Stream consisting of init, f(init), f(f(init)), etc.

      The first element (position 0) in the Stream will be the provided init. For n > 0, the element at position n, will be the result of applying the function f to the element at position n - 1.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the stream
      Parameters:
      init - the initial element
      hasNext - a predicate that returns true if the iteration should continue
      f - a function to apply to the previous element to generate the next element
      Returns:
      a stream of elements generated by the iteration
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the initial element, hasNext or f is null

    • iterate

      public static <T> Stream<T> iterate(T init, Predicate<? super T> hasNext, UnaryOperator<T> f) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a stream that iterates from an initial value, applying a function to generate subsequent values, and continues as long as a predicate is satisfied.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the stream
      Parameters:
      init - the initial value
      hasNext - test if has next by hasNext.test(init) for first time and hasNext.test(f.apply(previous)) for remaining.
      f - a function to apply to the previous element to generate the next element
      Returns:
      a stream of elements generated by the iteration
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the initial element, hasNext or f is null

    • iterate

      public static <T> Stream<T> iterate(T init, UnaryOperator<T> f) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Creates a stream that iterates over elements starting from the given initial value. Each subsequent element is generated by applying the provided unary operator to the previous element.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the stream
      Parameters:
      init - the initial element
      f - the function to apply to the previous element to produce the next element
      Returns:
      a stream of elements generated by iterating with the given function
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the initial element or f is null

    • generate

      public static <T> Stream<T> generate(Supplier<T> supplier) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Generates a Stream using the provided Supplier. The supplier is used to generate each element of the stream.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the stream
      Parameters:
      supplier - the Supplier that provides the elements of the stream
      Returns:
      a Stream generated by the given supplier
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the supplier is null

      public static Stream<String> ofLines(Reader reader)

      It's user's responsibility to close the input reader after the stream is completed.
      Parameters:
      reader - the Reader to read lines from
      Returns:
      a Stream of lines read from the Reader

    • interval

      public static <T> Stream<T> interval(long intervalInMillis, Supplier<T> s)

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements generated by the stream
      Parameters:
      intervalInMillis - the interval in milliseconds between each element generation
      s - the supplier that generates the elements
      Returns:
      a stream that generates elements at the specified interval

    • interval

      public static <T> Stream<T> interval(long delayInMillis, long intervalInMillis, Supplier<T> s)
      Creates a stream that generates elements at fixed intervals after an initial delay.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements generated by the stream
      Parameters:
      delayInMillis - the initial delay in milliseconds before the first element is generated
      intervalInMillis - the interval in milliseconds between each element generation
      s - the supplier that generates the elements
      Returns:
      a stream that generates elements at the specified interval after the initial delay

      public static <T> Stream<T> interval(long delay, long interval, TimeUnit unit, Supplier<T> s) throws IllegalArgumentException

      T - the type of elements generated by the stream
      Parameters:
      delay - the initial delay before the first element is generated
      interval - the interval between each element generation
      unit - the time unit of the delay and interval
      s - the supplier that generates the elements
      Returns:
      a stream that generates elements at the specified interval after the initial delay
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the supplier is null

      public static <T> Stream<T> interval(long intervalInMillis, LongFunction<? extends T> s)

      Parameters:
      intervalInMillis - the interval in milliseconds between each element generation
      s - the function that generates the elements based on the current time in milliseconds

      a stream that generates elements at the specified interval

      IllegalArgumentException - if the function is null

      Parameters:

      interval - the interval between each element generation
      unit - the time unit of the delay and interval
      s - the function that generates the elements based on the current time in the specified unit
      Returns:
      a stream that generates elements at the specified interval after the initial delay
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the function is null

    • observe

      @Beta public static <T> Stream<T> observe(BlockingQueue<T> queue, Duration duration) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Observes a blocking queue and creates a stream that polls elements from the queue in the specified duration. 
       
 final BlockingQueue queue = new ArrayBlockingQueueinvalid input: '<'>(32);
 N.asyncExecute(() -> Stream.observe(queue, Duration.ofMillis(100)).filter(s -> s.startsWith("a")).forEach(Fn.println()));
 N.asList("a", "b", "ab", "bc", "1", "a").forEach(queue::add);
 N.sleep(10);
 N.println("==================");
 N.sleep(100);
 N.println("==================");
 N.sleep(10);
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the queue
      Parameters:
      queue - the blocking queue to observe
      duration - the total time to observe the queue
      Returns:
      a stream that polls elements from the queue at the specified interval
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the queue or duration is null

    • observe

      @Beta public static <T> Stream<T> observe(BlockingQueue<T> queue, BooleanSupplier hasMore, long maxWaitIntervalInMillis) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Observes a blocking queue and creates a stream that polls elements from the queue at fixed intervals. 
       
 final BlockingQueue queue = new ArrayBlockingQueueinvalid input: '<'>(32);
 final MutableBoolean hasMore = MutableBoolean.of(true);
 N.asyncExecute(() -> Stream.observe(queue, () -> hasMore.value(), 10).filter(s -> s.startsWith("a")).forEach(Fn.println()));
 N.asList("a", "b", "ab", "bc", "1", "a").forEach(queue::add);
 N.println("==================");
 hasMore.setFalse();
 N.sleep(50);
 N.println("==================");
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the queue
      Parameters:
      queue - the blocking queue to observe
      hasMore - it will will be set to true if Stream is completed and the upstream should not continue to put elements to queue when it's completed. This is an output parameter.
      maxWaitIntervalInMillis - the maximum wait interval in milliseconds between polling the queue
      Returns:
      a stream that polls elements from the queue at the specified interval
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the queue or hasMore is null, or if maxWaitIntervalInMillis is negative

    • parallelConcat

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelConcat(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams)

      Parameters:

    • parallelConcat

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelConcat(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams, int readThreadNum)
      Returns a Stream with elements from a temporary queue which is filled by fetching elements from the specified streams in parallel with multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the streams
      Parameters:
      streams - the collection of stream to be concatenated
      readThreadNum - - count of threads used to read elements from iterator to queue. Default value is min(64, cup_cores)
      Returns:
      a parallel stream containing all the elements of the provided streams

    • parallelConcat

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelConcat(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams, int readThreadNum, int bufferSize)
      Returns a Stream with elements from a temporary queue which is filled by fetching elements from the specified streams in parallel with multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of elements in the streams
      Parameters:
      streams - the collection of stream to be concatenated
      readThreadNum - - count of threads used to read elements from iterator to queue. Default value is min(64, cup_cores)
      bufferSize - the size of the buffer used to store elements from the iterators read by the reading threads.
      Returns:
      a parallel stream containing all the elements of the provided streams

    • parallelConcatIterators

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelConcatIterators(Collection<? extends Iterator<? extends T>> iterators)

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(char[] a, char[] b, CharBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips two arrays of characters into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first array of characters
      b - the second array of characters
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the arrays
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(char[] a, char[] b, char[] c, CharTriFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips three arrays of characters into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each triple of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first array of characters
      b - the second array of characters
      c - the third array of characters
      zipFunction - the function to combine triples of values from the arrays
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(CharIterator a, CharIterator b, CharBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)

      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first character iterator
      b - the second character iterator
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterators
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(Collection<? extends CharStream> c, CharNFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips a collection of character streams into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each set of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      c - the collection of character streams
      zipFunction - the function to combine sets of values from the streams
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(char[] a, char[] b, char valueForNoneA, char valueForNoneB, CharBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips two character arrays into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one array runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA or valueForNoneB is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first character array
      b - the second character array
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first array runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second array runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the arrays
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(char[] a, char[] b, char[] c, char valueForNoneA, char valueForNoneB, char valueForNoneC, CharTriFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips three character arrays into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each triple of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one array runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA, valueForNoneB or valueForNoneC is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first character array
      b - the second character array
      c - the third character array
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first array runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second array runs out of values
      valueForNoneC - the value to use if the third array runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine triples of values from the arrays
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(CharIterator a, CharIterator b, char valueForNoneA, char valueForNoneB, CharBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips two character iterators into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one iterator runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA or valueForNoneB is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first character iterator
      b - the second character iterator
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first iterator runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second iterator runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterators
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(CharIterator a, CharIterator b, CharIterator c, char valueForNoneA, char valueForNoneB, char valueForNoneC, CharTriFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips three character iterators into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each triple of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one iterator runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA, valueForNoneB or valueForNoneC is used.

      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second iterator runs out of values
      valueForNoneC - the value to use if the third iterator runs out of values

      a stream of combined values

      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(int[] a, int[] b, int[] c, int valueForNoneA, int valueForNoneB, int valueForNoneC, IntTriFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips three int arrays into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each triple of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one array runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA, valueForNoneB or valueForNoneC is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first int array
      b - the second int array
      c - the third int array
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first array runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second array runs out of values
      valueForNoneC - the value to use if the third array runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine triples of values from the arrays

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(IntIterator a, IntIterator b, int valueForNoneA, int valueForNoneB, IntBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips two int iterators into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one iterator runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA or valueForNoneB is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first int iterator
      b - the second int iterator
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first iterator runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second iterator runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterators
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

      Parameters:

      valuesForNone - the values to use if the streams run out of values

      a stream of combined values

      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first double array
      b - the second double array
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first array runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second array runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the arrays
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(double[] a, double[] b, double[] c, double valueForNoneA, double valueForNoneB, double valueForNoneC, DoubleTriFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips three double arrays into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each triple of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one array runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA, valueForNoneB or valueForNoneC is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first double array
      b - the second double array
      c - the third double array
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first array runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second array runs out of values
      valueForNoneC - the value to use if the third array runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine triples of values from the arrays

    • zip

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(DoubleIterator a, DoubleIterator b, double valueForNoneA, double valueForNoneB, DoubleBiFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips two double iterators into a single stream until all of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one iterator runs out of values before the other, the specified valueForNoneA or valueForNoneB is used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first double iterator
      b - the second double iterator
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first iterator runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second iterator runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterators
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

      Zips three double streams into a single stream until all of them run out of values. Each set of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one stream runs out of values before the others, the specified valueForNoneA, valueForNoneB, or valueForNoneC is used.

      public static <R> Stream<R> zip(Collection<? extends DoubleStream> c, double[] valuesForNone, DoubleNFunction<? extends R> zipFunction)
      Zips a collection of double streams into a single stream until all of them run out of values. Each set of values is combined into a single value using the supplied zipFunction. If one stream runs out of values before the others, the specified valuesForNone are used.
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      c - the collection of double streams
      valuesForNone - the values to use if the streams run out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine sets of values from the streams
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • parallelZip

      public static <A, B, R> Stream<R> parallelZip(Iterable<? extends A> a, Iterable<? extends B> b, BiFunction<? super A,? super B,? extends R> zipFunction, int maxThreadNumForZipFunction)
      Zips two iterables into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value by the provided zipFunction, which will be executed by multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      A - the type of the elements in the first iterable
      B - the type of the elements in the second iterable
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first iterable
      b - the second iterable
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterables
      maxThreadNumForZipFunction - the max thread number for the zipFunction.
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • parallelZip

      public static <A, B, R> Stream<R> parallelZip(Iterator<? extends A> a, Iterator<? extends B> b, BiFunction<? super A,? super B,? extends R> zipFunction, int maxThreadNumForZipFunction)
      Zips two iterators into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value by the provided zipFunction, which will be executed by multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      A - the type of the elements in the first iterator
      B - the type of the elements in the second iterator
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first iterator
      b - the second iterator
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterators
      maxThreadNumForZipFunction - the max thread number for the zipFunction.
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • parallelZip

      • buffered(int)

    • parallelZip

      public static <A, B, C, R> Stream<R> parallelZip(Iterable<? extends A> a, Iterable<? extends B> b, Iterable<? extends C> c, TriFunction<? super A,? super B,? super C,? extends R> zipFunction, int maxThreadNumForZipFunction)
      Zips three iterables into a single stream until one of them runs out of values. Each triplet of values is combined into a single value by the provided zipFunction, which will be executed by multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      A - the type of the elements in the first iterable
      B - the type of the elements in the second iterable
      C - the type of the elements in the third iterable
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first iterable
      b - the second iterable
      c - the third iterable
      zipFunction - the function to combine triplets of values from the iterables
      maxThreadNumForZipFunction - the max thread number for the zipFunction.
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • parallelZip

    • parallelZip

      public static <A, B, R> Stream<R> parallelZip(Iterable<? extends A> a, Iterable<? extends B> b, A valueForNoneA, B valueForNoneB, BiFunction<? super A,? super B,? extends R> zipFunction, int maxThreadNumForZipFunction)
      Zips two iterables into a single stream until all of them run out of values. Each pair of values is combined into a single value by the provided zipFunction, which will be executed by multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      A - the type of the elements in the first iterable
      B - the type of the elements in the second iterable
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      a - the first iterable
      b - the second iterable
      valueForNoneA - the value to use if the first iterable runs out of values
      valueForNoneB - the value to use if the second iterable runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine pairs of values from the iterables
      maxThreadNumForZipFunction - the max thread number for the zipFunction.
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values

    • parallelZip

      public static <T, R> Stream<R> parallelZip(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams, List<? extends T> valuesForNone, Function<? super List<T>,? extends R> zipFunction, int maxThreadNumForZipFunction)
      Zips multiple streams into a single stream until all of them run out of values. Each list of values is combined into a single value by the provided zipFunction, which will be executed by multiple threads.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the streams
      R - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      streams - the collection of stream
      valuesForNone - the values to use if any stream runs out of values
      zipFunction - the function to combine lists of values from the streams
      maxThreadNumForZipFunction - the max thread number for the zipFunction.
      Returns:
      a stream of combined values
      See Also:
      • buffered()

    • merge

      public static <T> Stream<T> merge(T[] a, T[] b, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,MergeResult> nextSelector)
      Merges two arrays into a single stream based on the provided nextSelector function. The nextSelector function determines which element from the two arrays should be selected next.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the arrays
      Parameters:
      a - the first array to be merged. It should be ordered.
      b - the second array to be merged. It should be ordered.
      nextSelector - a function that determines the next element to be selected from the two arrays
      Returns:
      a stream containing the merged elements from the two arrays
      See Also:
      • N.merge(Object[], Object[], BiFunction)

    • merge

      public static <T> Stream<T> merge(T[] a, T[] b, T[] c, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,MergeResult> nextSelector)
      Merges three arrays into a single stream based on the provided nextSelector function. The nextSelector function determines which element from the three arrays should be selected next.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the arrays
      Parameters:
      a - the first array to be merged. It should be ordered.
      b - the second array to be merged. It should be ordered.
      c - the third array to be merged. It should be ordered.
      nextSelector - a function that determines the next element to be selected from the three arrays
      Returns:
      a stream containing the merged elements from the three arrays
      See Also:
      • N.merge(Object[], Object[], BiFunction)

      Merges a collection of iterator into a single stream based on the provided nextSelector function. The nextSelector function determines which element from the iterators should be selected next.

    • parallelMerge

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelMerge(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,MergeResult> nextSelector)
      Merges a collection of stream into a single stream in parallel. All the elements from each input stream will be merged into two queues by multiple threads first. Then these two new queues will be merged into one stream. This method is not totally lazy evaluation and may cause out of memory error if there are too many elements merged into the two new queues. Consider using merge, which is totally lazy evaluation.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the streams
      Parameters:
      streams - the collection of stream to be merged. It should be ordered.
      nextSelector - a function to determine which element should be selected as next element.
      Returns:
      a stream containing the merged elements from the collection of stream
      See Also:
      • merge(Collection, BiFunction)

    • parallelMerge

      public static <T> Stream<T> parallelMerge(Collection<? extends Stream<? extends T>> streams, BiFunction<? super T,? super T,MergeResult> nextSelector, int maxThreadNum) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Merges a collection of stream into a single stream in parallel. All the elements from each input stream will be merged into two queues by multiple threads first. Then these two new queues will be merged into one stream. This method is not totally lazy evaluation and may cause out of memory error if there are too many elements merged into the two new queues. Consider using merge, which is totally lazy evaluation.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the streams
      Parameters:
      streams - the collection of stream to be merged. It should be ordered.
      nextSelector - a function to determine which element should be selected as next element.
      maxThreadNum - the max thread number for the parallel merge.
      Returns:
      a stream containing the merged elements from the collection of stream
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException
      See Also:
      • merge(Collection, BiFunction)

    • parallelMergeIterables

      Merges a collection of iterable into a single stream in parallel. All the elements from each input iterable will be merged into two queues by multiple threads first. Then these two new queues will be merged into one stream. This method is not totally lazy evaluation and may cause out of memory error if there are too many elements merged into the two new queues. Consider using merge, which is totally lazy evaluation.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the elements in the iterables
      Parameters:
      iterables - the collection of iterable to be merged. It should be ordered.
      nextSelector - a function to determine which element should be selected as next element.
      Returns:
      a stream containing the merged elements from the collection of iterable
      See Also:
      • mergeIterables(Collection, BiFunction)

    • shuffled

      public Stream<T> shuffled()
      Description copied from interface: BaseStream
      Returns a stream consisting of the elements of this stream in a shuffled order. All elements will be loaded to memory when this method is called.
      This method only runs sequentially, even in parallel stream.
      Specified by:
      shuffled in interface BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER extends Iterator<T>,S extends BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER,S>>
      Returns:
      A new Stream consisting of the elements of this stream in a shuffled order.

    • elementAt

      public u.Optional<T> elementAt(long position) throws IllegalStateException, IllegalArgumentException
      Description copied from interface: BaseStream
      Returns the element at the specified position in this stream. The position is zero-based, meaning the first element in the stream has a position of 0, the second has a position of 1, and so on.

    • sequential

      public Stream<T> sequential()
      Description copied from interface: BaseStream
      Switches the stream to sequential mode. In sequential mode, the operations on the stream are performed in the order of the elements in the stream. This is an intermediate operation.
      Specified by:
      sequential in interface BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER extends Iterator<T>,S extends BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER,S>>
      Returns:
      A new Stream that is identical to this stream, but in sequential mode.

    • parallel

      public Stream<T> parallel()
      Description copied from interface: BaseStream
      Switches the stream to sequential mode. In sequential mode, the operations on the stream are performed in the order of the elements in the stream. This is an intermediate operation.
      Consider using sps(Function) if only next operation need to be parallelized. For example: 
       stream.parallel().map(f).filter(p)...;

 // Replace above line of code with "sps" if only "f" need to be parallelized. And "p" is fast enough to be executed in sequential Stream.
 stream.sps(s -> s.map(f)).filter(p)...;
 // Or switch the stream back sequential stream if don't use "sps".
 stream.parallel().map(f).sequential().filter(p)...;
      In most scenarios, there could be only one operation need be parallelized in the stream. So sps(Function) is recommended in most of scenarios.
      Specified by:
      parallel in interface BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER extends Iterator<T>,S extends BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER,S>>
      Returns:
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.parallel(Executor)
      • BaseStream.parallel(int, Executor)
      • BaseStream.parallel(int, Splitor, Executor)
      • BaseStream.sps(Function)
      • BaseStream.sps(int, Function)

    • parallel

      public Stream<T> parallel(int maxThreadNum)
      Description copied from interface: BaseStream
      Switches the stream to sequential mode. In sequential mode, the operations on the stream are performed in the order of the elements in the stream. This is an intermediate operation.
      Consider using sps(int, Function) if only next operation need to be parallelized. For example: 
       stream.parallel(maxThreadNum).map(f).filter(p)...;

 // Replace above line of code with "sps" if only "f" need to be parallelized. And "p" is fast enough to be executed in sequential Stream.
 stream.sps(maxThreadNum, s -> s.map(f)).filter(p)...;
 // Or switch the stream back sequential stream if don't use "sps".
 stream.parallel(maxThreadNum).map(f).sequential().filter(p)...;
      In most scenarios, there could be only one operation need be parallelized in the stream. So sps(int, Function) is recommended in most of scenarios.
      Specified by:
      parallel in interface BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER extends Iterator<T>,S extends BaseStream<T,A,P,C,OT,IT,ITER,S>>
      Parameters:
      maxThreadNum - if the specified value is bigger than the maximum allowed thread number per operation (min(64, cpu_cores * 8)), maximum allowed thread number per operation will be used. To parallelize this Stream with thread number bigger than min(64, cpu_cores * 8), please specified executor by calling BaseStream.parallel(int, Executor) or BaseStream.parallel(int, Splitor, Executor) or BaseStream.parallel(ParallelSettings)
      Returns:
      See Also:
      • BaseStream.parallel(Executor)
      • BaseStream.parallel(int, Executor)
      • BaseStream.parallel(int, Splitor, Executor)
      • BaseStream.sps(Function)
      • BaseStream.sps(int, Function)

    • parallel
